questions:
A 22-year-old woman attends her GP with recurrent, smelly discharge from her right ear with a reduced hearing on the affected side. Episodes were usually every few months but she is noticing the discharge on most days now. As a child, she swam frequently and had grommet insertion for glue ear which fell out around the age of 9. She has no other past medical history and her only medication is the combined oral contraceptive pill.

Hearing tests are performed which show:

Rinne's test (right side)bone conduction > air conduction
Rinne's test (left side)air conduction > bone conduction
Weber's testlateralisation to right

What diagnosis should be suspected?
notes:
This patient is presenting with a right-sided conductive hearing loss as she has Rinne's test showing bone conduction > air conduction in the affected ear and Weber's test that lateralises to the right (affected ear). Cholesteatoma is an example of a conductive hearing loss that is also associated with chronic, smelly ear discharge and recurrent glue ear. The vignette depicts a patient who is experiencing both recurrent ear discharge and has a history of glue ear which makes this the most likely diagnosis. Cholesteatoma occurs due to squamous epithelium forming in small pockets on the tympanic membrane which becomes cyst-like as it produces keratin and sloughs over time. There will be middle ear erosion which will create an environment for anaerobic bacterial growth to occur.

Acoustic neuroma causes sensorineural hearing loss. It is associated with dizziness and typically causes unilateral hearing loss. Sensorineural hearing loss is seen as air conduction >bone conduction in both ears and Weber test lateralising to the unaffected ear. Over time, patients with acoustic neuroma develop neurological symptoms as the tumour grows. Neurological symptoms can be predicted by the affected cranial nerves:

Cranial nerve VIII: hearing loss, vertigo, tinnitus.
Cranial nerve V: absent corneal reflex.
Cranial nerve VII: facial palsy.

Otitis externa is an acute infection of the outer ear associated with ear pain or itching and occasionally discharge from the affected ear. It commonly affects swimmers. It can cause a conductive hearing loss as shown above. As the patient has a chronic history, this answer is less likely. Furthermore, her lack of ear pain should lead to consideration of other diagnoses.

Otosclerosis presents with progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. It is an autosomal dominant trait so patients are typically aged 20-40 years and will have a strong family history of early-onset hearing loss. It occurs as the normal bone in the middle ear is replaced by vascular spongy bone causing conductive hearing loss as the stapes becomes adherent to the oval window. As it does not typically present with smelly ear discharge, the student should consider alternative options first.

Tympanosclerosis is caused by the calcification of collagenous scar tissue on the inner tympanic membrane and middle ear following otitis media or trauma to the tympanic membrane. Patients may be asymptomatic or develop unilateral conductive hearing loss. There may be a chalky patch on the tympanic membrane seen on otoscopy or there may be total middle ear destruction. This is not the most likely diagnosis as the patient is complaining of chronic otorrhoea which differs from the typical presentation of tympanosclerosis.

title: Rinne's and Weber's test
body:
Performing both Rinne's and Weber's test allows differentiation of conductive and sensorineural deafness.

Rinne's test
  • tuning fork is placed over the mastoid process until the sound is no longer heard, followed by repositioning just over external acoustic meatus
  • 'positive test': air conduction (AC) is normally better than bone conduction (BC)
  • 'negative test': if BC > AC then conductive deafness

Weber's test
  • tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead equidistant from the patient's ears
  • the patient is then asked which side is loudest
  • in unilateral sensorineural deafness, sound is localised to the unaffected side
  • in unilateral conductive deafness, sound is localised to the affected side

Interpretation of Rinne and Weber tests

Rinne resultWeber result
Normal Air conduction > bone conduction bilaterallyMidline
Conductive hearing lossBone conduction > air conduction in affected ear
Air conduction > bone conduction in unaffected ear		Lateralises to affected ear
Sensorineural hearing lossAir conduction > bone conduction bilaterallyLateralises to unaffected ear
concept:
Conductive hearing loss
  • Rinne result: Bone conduction > air conduction in affected ear, Air conduction > bone conduction in unaffected ear
  • Weber result: Lateralises to affected ear
links:
ENT SHO2319
Guide to the ear examination
media:
Weber vs. Rinne Test & Conductive vs. Sensorineural Hearing Loss
DirtyUSMLE - YouTube471
 
Understanding the Causes of Hearing Loss
Zero To Finals - YouTube61

11374.concept_text:
Sensorineural hearing loss
   - Rinne result: Air conduction > bone conduction bilaterally
   - Weber result: Lateralises to unaffected ear

11375.concept_text:
Conductive hearing loss
   - Rinne result: Bone conduction > air conduction in affected ear, Air conduction > bone conduction in unaffected ear
   - Weber result: Lateralises to affected ear

11376.concept_text:
Normal hearing
   - Rinne result: Air conduction > bone conduction bilaterally
   - Weber result: same in both ears

theme: Next step in uncontrolled asthma after MART, LTRA and LAMA.
options: Arrange fractional exhaled nitric oxide testing
Prescribe a short course of oral corticosteroids
Arrange referral to a respiratory specialist
questions:
A 28-year-old with asthma attends a review. They use a moderate-dose ICS/formoterol inhaler as MART. Despite sequential trials of a leukotriene receptor antagonist and a long-acting muscarinic antagonist, they still use their reliever multiple times daily and have occasional nocturnal symptoms.

Select the single most appropriate management from the options below
notes:
Arrange referral to a respiratory specialist is the correct answer. According to the 2024 joint NICE/BTS/SIGN guidelines for asthma management in adults, this patient has reached Step 5 of the treatment pathway. They are already on moderate-dose Maintenance and Reliever Therapy (MART), which is Step 3. The scenario describes a failure to achieve control despite trials of both a leukotriene receptor antagonist (LTRA) and a long-acting muscarinic antagonist (LAMA), which constitutes Step 4 of the management algorithm. The guideline is explicit that when asthma remains uncontrolled despite treatment with moderate-dose MART and sequential trials of both an LTRA and a LAMA, the next step is referral to a specialist in asthma care. This allows for a more detailed assessment, confirmation of the diagnosis, exclusion of mimics, and consideration of more advanced therapies such as high-dose inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) or biologic agents. The patient's ongoing symptoms (daily reliever use, nocturnal waking) clearly indicate that their asthma is not well-controlled, mandating escalation of care to a specialist setting as per the national evidence-based pathway.

Increase to high-dose MART is an incorrect next step in primary care. While escalating the dose of ICS is a key principle of asthma management, the guidelines recommend that the initiation of high-dose ICS should be undertaken following specialist assessment. Moving to high-dose ICS significantly increases the risk of systemic side effects, and it is crucial to first confirm the diagnosis, ensure optimal adherence and inhaler technique, and consider alternative diagnoses or phenotypes of asthma that may respond better to other treatments (e.g., biologics). The referral threshold is specifically set after failure of moderate-dose MART plus add-on therapies to ensure that these complex cases receive specialist input before committing the patient to the risks of long-term high-dose steroid treatment.

Arrange fractional exhaled nitric oxide testing is incorrect at this stage. Fractional exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO) testing is recommended at Step 4 of the guideline, before the trials of an LTRA or LAMA. At that point, a raised FeNO or blood eosinophil count would prompt an earlier referral to a specialist. If these markers are not raised, a trial of an LTRA and then a LAMA is recommended. Since this patient has already completed these trials, the point for this investigation has passed. The indication for referral is now based on the failure of treatment, regardless of the FeNO level. Repeating or performing this test now would not change the immediate management plan, which is to refer.

Prescribe a short course of oral corticosteroids is not appropriate for this clinical scenario. Oral corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone) are reserved for the management of acute, severe exacerbations of asthma. This patient is presenting with chronic, poorly controlled symptoms rather than a distinct and severe worsening. While their control is suboptimal, there is no indication of a medical emergency requiring rescue steroids. The goal here is to optimise their long-term maintenance therapy to prevent future exacerbations and improve day-to-day symptoms, which requires a strategic change in their regular treatment, not a short-term rescue course.

Add oral theophylline is an incorrect option. Theophylline is a third- or fourth-line agent that is now rarely used in primary care due to its narrow therapeutic index, need for monitoring of plasma levels, and significant potential for drug interactions and side effects (e.g., arrhythmias, seizures). Its use is generally reserved for specialist practice in patients with difficult-to-control asthma who have failed other standard therapies. It would not be considered as the next step by a GP in this situation; referral to a specialist, who might then consider agents like theophylline, is the appropriate pathway.

title: Asthma: management in adults
body:
In 2024 NICE, the British Thoracic Society and SIGN produced joint guidelines on the management of asthma following many years of conflicting guidelines. The new guidelines represent a major step change in the management of asthma is both diagnosed and treated.

For many years patients with asthma were started on a short-acting beta-2 agonist (SABA) inhaler before 'stepping up' to a regular inhaled corticosteroid with a SABA as required. The new guidelines now advocate the use of combined inhalers (ICS + long-acting beta-2 agonist) as reliever therapy or regularly, depending on the severity of asthma. Given the prevalence of asthma, it is likely that doctors will have to deal with patients on 'conventional' asthma treatments for many years to come. The joint guidelines therefore include guidance on how to manage these patients if their current treatment is controlling their symptoms sufficiently.

Management of adult patients aged children aged ≥ 12 years with newly diagnosed asthma

Step 1 NICE
  • a low-dose inhaled corticosteroid (ICS)/formoterol combination inhaler to be taken as needed for symptom relief
    • this is termed anti-inflammatory reliever (AIR) therapy
  • if the patient presents highly symptomatic (for example, regular nocturnal waking) or with a severe exacerbation:
    • start treatment with low-dose MART (maintenance and reliever therapy, see below)
    • treat the acute symptoms as appropriate (e.g. a course of oral corticosteroids may be indicated)

Step 2 NICE
  • a low-dose MART
    • MART describes using an inhaled corticosteroid (ICS)/formoterol combination inhaler for daily maintenance therapy and the relief of symptoms as needed, i.e. regularly and as required

Step 3
  • a moderate-dose MART

Step 4
  • check the fractional exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO) level if available, and the blood eosinophil count NICE
    • if either of these is raised, refer to a specialist in asthma care
    • if neither FeNO nor eosinophil count is raised, consider a trial of either a leukotriene receptor antagonist (LTRA) or a long-acting muscarinic receptor antagonist (LAMA) used in addition to moderate-dose MART
    • if control has not improved, stop the LTRA or LAMA and start a trial of the alternative medicine (LTRA or LAMA)

Step 5
  • refer people to a specialist in asthma care when asthma is not controlled despite treatment with moderate-dose MART, and trials of an LTRA and a LAMA


Transferring people aged 12 and over from other treatment pathways

There will be many people whose asthma was managed according to the previous guidelines that present with uncontrolled asthmatic symptoms. The guidelines give advice on how these people should be switched: NICE

Existing asthma treatmentNew asthma treatment
SABA as required only Low-dose ICS/formoterol combination inhaler used as needed (as-needed AIR therapy)
SABA as required + regular low-dose ICS
SABA as required + regular low-dose ICS/LABA
SABA as required + regular low-dose ICS + LTRA
SABA as required + regular low-dose ICS/LABA + LTRA		Regular low-dose regular ICS/formoterol combination inhaler (MART therapy)
SABA as required + regular moderate-dose ICS
SABA as required + regular moderate-dose ICS/LABA
SABA as required + regular moderate-dose ICS + LTRA or LAMA
SABA as required + regular moderate-dose ICS/LABA + LTRA or LAMA		Regular moderate-dose MART therapy
Treatment regime containing a high-dose ICSRefer to a respiratory specialist
concept: Refer adults to a respiratory specialist when asthma is not controlled despite treatment with moderate-dose MART, and trials of an LTRA and a LAMA
links:
NICE4811
2024 Asthma: diagnosis, monitoring and chronic asthma management (BTS, NICE, SIGN)
media:
Inhaler and Nebuliser Explanation
Oxford Medical Education - YouTube31

12286.concept_text: Asthma: adults and children ≥ 12 years first-line treatment --> low-dose inhaled corticosteroid (ICS)/formoterol combination inhaler as required

12287.concept_text: Asthma: adults and children ≥ 12 years second-line treatment --> low-dose inhaled corticosteroid (ICS)/formoterol combination inhaler regularly and as required (MART)

12288.concept_text: Asthma: adults and children ≥ 12 years not controlled on low-dose MART --> moderate-dose MART

12289.concept_text: Asthma: adults not controlled on moderate-dose MART --> check the FeNO level if available, and the blood eosinophil count

12290.concept_text: Asthma: adults not controlled on moderate-dose MART - if either FeNO level or blood eosinophil raised then --> refer to a respiratory specialist

12291.concept_text: Asthma: adults not controlled on moderate-dose MART - if neither FeNO level nor blood eosinophil raised -->  trial of either a LTRA or a LAMA

12292.concept_text: Refer adults to a respiratory specialist when asthma is not controlled despite treatment with moderate-dose MART, and trials of an LTRA and a LAMA

12294.concept_text: Adults with asthma who are poorly controlled on SABA prn + regularly ICS --> regular low-dose regular ICS/formoterol combination inhaler (MART therapy)

12295.concept_text: If an adult presents with highly symptomatic asthma (for example, regular nocturnal waking) or with a severe exacerbation then treat the acute symptoms and start MART

questions:
A 36-year-old male presents with chest pain, the chest pain is left-sided and dull in nature. It has been present for a period of five days. There is no associated shortness of breath, cough, collapse or pleuritic nature of the chest pain. He describes a recent sore throat and headache last week which has since resolved. There is no family history in a first-degree relative of sudden cardiac death and the patient has never smoked.

Blood pressure 125/89 mmHg, heart rate 95/min, temperature 37.3ºC, oxygen saturations 97% on room air. Pulsus paradoxus is not present.

Blood results reveal:


Hb154 g/LMale: (135-180)
Female: (115 - 160)
Platelets425 * 109/L(150 - 400)
WBC11.5 * 109/L(4.0 - 11.0)
Na+137 mmol/L(135 - 145)
K+4.6 mmol/L(3.5 - 5.0)
Urea6.4 mmol/L(2.0 - 7.0)
Creatinine100 µmol/L(55 - 120)
CRP40 mg/L(< 5)
Troponin T13 ng/L(<14)

Electrocardiogram (ECG): ST-segment elevation in lead I, II, III, aVL, V5 and V6. PR segment elevation in aVR.

What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
notes:
This patient has pericarditis. His young age, widespread ST-segment elevation and troponin within the normal range point towards pericarditis. While typically pericarditis is associated with PR segment depression, note that the PR segment will be elevated in aVR.

Myocarditis would be diagnosed if this patient had a raised troponin.

Infective endocarditis is less likely with a normal temperature and ECG changes consistent with pericarditis.

Cardiac tamponade is a complication of pericarditis but is unlikely to be present in this case as he has normal blood pressure and pulsus paradoxus is not present.

Myocardial infarction is unlikely in this patient due to his age, lack of risk factors and uncharacteristic ECG changes. His troponin is also within the normal range.

title: Acute pericarditis
body:
Acute pericarditis is a condition referring to inflammation of the pericardial sac, lasting for less than 4-6 weeks.

Aetiology
  • viral infections (Coxsackie)
  • tuberculosis
  • uraemia
  • post-myocardial infarction
    • early (1-3 days): fibrinous pericarditis
    • late (weeks to months): autoimmune pericarditis (Dressler's syndrome)
  • radiotherapy
  • connective tissue disease
    • systemic lupus erythematosus
    • rheumatoid arthritis
  • hypothyroidism
  • malignancy
    • lung cancer
    • breast cancer
  • trauma

Features
  • chest pain: may be pleuritic. Is often relieved by sitting forwards
  • other symptoms include a non-productive cough, dyspnoea and flu-like symptoms
  • pericardial rub

Investigations
  • ECG changes
    • the changes in pericarditis are often global/widespread, as opposed to the 'territories' seen in ischaemic events
    • 'saddle-shaped' ST elevation
    • PR depression: most specific ECG marker for pericarditis
  • all patients with suspected acute pericarditis should have transthoracic echocardiography
  • bloods
    • inflammatory markers
    • troponin: around 30% of patients may have an elevated troponin - this indicates possible myopericarditis


Management
  • the majority of patients can be managed as outpatients
    • patients who have high-risk features such as fever > 38°C or elevated troponin should be managed as an inpatient
  • treat any underlying cause
    • most patients however will have pericarditis secondary to viral infection, meaning no specific treatment is indicated
  • strenuous physical activity should be avoided until symptom resolution and normalisation of inflammatory markers
    • athletes should avoid strenuous exercise for at least 3 months until symptoms have resolved and investigations (CRP, ECG, and echocardiography) have normalised
  • a combination of NSAIDs and colchicine is now generally used for first-line for patients with acute idiopathic or viral pericarditis
    • therapy is continued until symptom resolution and normalisation of inflammatory markers (usually 1–2 weeks), followed by a taper of the dose over a further 2–4 weeks
concept: Global ST and PR segment changes: think pericarditis

1281.concept_text: Saddle-shaped ST elevation is often seen in the ECG of a patient with acute pericarditis

9669.concept_text: Global ST and PR segment changes: think pericarditis

options: On the distal ventral surface of the penis
On the proximal ventral surface of the penis
On the distal dorsal surface of the penis
On the proximal dorsal surface of the penis
At the base of the scrotum
questions: A 3 month old boy is suspected of having hypospadias. At which of the following locations is the urethral opening most frequently located in boys suffering from the condition?
notes: The defect is located ventrally and most often distally. Proximally located urethral openings are well recognised. Circumcision may compromise reconstruction.
question: A 3 month old boy is suspected of having hypospadias. At which of the following locations is the urethral opening most frequently located in boys suffering from the condition?
question_notes: The defect is located ventrally and most often distally. Proximally located urethral openings are well recognised. Circumcision may compromise reconstruction.
title: Hypospadias
body:
Hypospadias is a congenital abnormality of the penis which occurs in approximately 3/1,000 male infants. There appears to be a significant genetic element, with further male children having a risk of around 5-15%.

It is usually identified on the newborn baby check. If missed, parents may notice an abnormal urine stream.

Hypospadias is characterised by
  • a ventral urethral meatus
  • a hooded prepuce
  • chordee (ventral curvature of the penis) in more severe forms
  • the urethral meatus may open more proximally in the more severe variants. However, 75% of the openings are distally located.


Hypospadias most commonly occurs as an isolated disorder. However, associated conditions include cryptorchidism (present in 10%) and inguinal hernia.

Management
  • once hypospadias has been identified, infants should be referred to specialist services
  • corrective surgery is typically performed when the child is around 12 months of age
  • it is essential that the child is not circumcised prior to the surgery as the foreskin may be used in the corrective procedure
  • in boys with very distal disease, no treatment may be needed.
media:
Hypospadias & epispadias
Osmosis - YouTube20

3694.concept_text: Hypospadias surgery is typically performed at around 12 months of age

11171.concept_text: Circumcision should not be performed for infants with hypospadias - the foreskin may be used in the corrective procedure

theme: First-line investigation for suspected lung cancer in primary care
questions:
A 62-year-old woman attends her GP with a 3-month history of persistent cough and unintentional weight loss of 4kg. She has a 35 pack-year smoking history. Examination reveals reduced breath sounds in the right upper zone.

Select the single most appropriate initial investigation from the options below.
notes:
Chest x-ray is the correct answer as it remains the first-line investigation for suspected lung cancer in primary care according to UK guidelines. This patient presents with red flag features including persistent cough, significant weight loss, and a substantial smoking history, all of which warrant investigation for possible lung cancer. A chest x-ray is readily accessible in primary care, cost-effective, and can identify suspicious lesions that require further investigation. It is important to note that approximately 10% of patients subsequently diagnosed with lung cancer have a normal initial chest x-ray, so if clinical suspicion remains high despite a normal result, further imaging with CT should be arranged. The chest x-ray serves as an appropriate screening tool that can be quickly arranged from general practice and helps determine the need for urgent referral and further investigation.

CT chest is the investigation of choice for characterising suspected lung cancer and is essential for staging, but it is not the first-line investigation in primary care. In UK practice, a chest x-ray should be performed first, and if this shows suspicious features or if clinical suspicion remains high despite a normal x-ray, then CT imaging would be arranged, typically through urgent suspected cancer referral pathways. Proceeding directly to CT without initial chest x-ray assessment would not follow standard primary care protocols.

Bronchoscopy is an important investigation for obtaining histological diagnosis through biopsy, sometimes with endobronchial ultrasound guidance, but it is a secondary care procedure performed after imaging has identified a suspicious lesion. It would not be arranged directly from primary care as the initial investigation. Bronchoscopy is typically organised by respiratory specialists following referral and initial imaging assessment.

PET-CT scan plays a valuable role in staging non-small cell lung cancer and determining eligibility for curative treatment by identifying local and distant metastatic spread. However, it is not used as a first-line diagnostic investigation in primary care. PET-CT would only be considered after a diagnosis has been established and is used specifically for treatment planning in appropriate cases.

Sputum cytology has poor sensitivity for diagnosing lung cancer and is not recommended as a first-line investigation in current UK practice. Whilst it may occasionally identify malignant cells, it cannot replace imaging for initial assessment. The low diagnostic yield and inability to localise lesions make it an inappropriate choice for investigating suspected lung cancer in this clinical scenario.
question:
A 62-year-old woman attends her GP with a 3-month history of persistent cough and unintentional weight loss of 4kg. She has a 35 pack-year smoking history. Examination reveals reduced breath sounds in the right upper zone.

Select the single most appropriate initial investigation from the options below.
question_notes:
Chest x-ray is the correct answer as it remains the first-line investigation for suspected lung cancer in primary care according to UK guidelines. This patient presents with red flag features including persistent cough, significant weight loss, and a substantial smoking history, all of which warrant investigation for possible lung cancer. A chest x-ray is readily accessible in primary care, cost-effective, and can identify suspicious lesions that require further investigation. It is important to note that approximately 10% of patients subsequently diagnosed with lung cancer have a normal initial chest x-ray, so if clinical suspicion remains high despite a normal result, further imaging with CT should be arranged. The chest x-ray serves as an appropriate screening tool that can be quickly arranged from general practice and helps determine the need for urgent referral and further investigation.

CT chest is the investigation of choice for characterising suspected lung cancer and is essential for staging, but it is not the first-line investigation in primary care. In UK practice, a chest x-ray should be performed first, and if this shows suspicious features or if clinical suspicion remains high despite a normal x-ray, then CT imaging would be arranged, typically through urgent suspected cancer referral pathways. Proceeding directly to CT without initial chest x-ray assessment would not follow standard primary care protocols.

Bronchoscopy is an important investigation for obtaining histological diagnosis through biopsy, sometimes with endobronchial ultrasound guidance, but it is a secondary care procedure performed after imaging has identified a suspicious lesion. It would not be arranged directly from primary care as the initial investigation. Bronchoscopy is typically organised by respiratory specialists following referral and initial imaging assessment.

PET-CT scan plays a valuable role in staging non-small cell lung cancer and determining eligibility for curative treatment by identifying local and distant metastatic spread. However, it is not used as a first-line diagnostic investigation in primary care. PET-CT would only be considered after a diagnosis has been established and is used specifically for treatment planning in appropriate cases.

Sputum cytology has poor sensitivity for diagnosing lung cancer and is not recommended as a first-line investigation in current UK practice. Whilst it may occasionally identify malignant cells, it cannot replace imaging for initial assessment. The low diagnostic yield and inability to localise lesions make it an inappropriate choice for investigating suspected lung cancer in this clinical scenario.
title: Lung cancer: investigation
body:
Chest x-ray
  • still the first-line investigation done in patients with suspected lung cancer who present to primary care
  • in around 10% of patients subsequently diagnosed with lung cancer the chest x-ray was reported as normal


CT
  • is the investigation of choice to investigate suspected lung cancer

Bronchoscopy
  • this allows a biopsy to be taken to obtain a histological diagnosis sometimes aided by endobronchial ultrasound

PET scanning
  • is typically done in non-small cell lung cancer to establish eligibility for curative treatment
  • uses 18-fluorodeoxygenase which is preferentially taken up by neoplastic tissue
  • has been shown to improve diagnostic sensitivity of both local and distant metastasis spread in non-small cell lung cancer

Bloods
  • raised platelets may be seen
concept: Chest x-ray is still the first-line investigation done in patients with suspected lung cancer who present to primary care
links:
Royal College of Physicians36
2012 PET/CT in oncology review


Radiopaedia33
Lung cancer review
media:
Cancers of the lung
MedLecturesMadeEasy - YouTube50
 
Lung Cancer: An Overview
Oncology for Medical Students - YouTube00
 
Lung cancer
Armando Hasudungan - YouTube00

options: Stop lisinopril and arrange investigations to exclude renal artery stenosis
Switch to a angiotensin 2 receptor blocker
Switch to a different ACE inhibitor
questions:
A 45-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus is reviewed in the diabetes clinic. Three months ago her blood tests were as followed:

K+4.5 mmol/l
Creatinine116 µmol/l
eGFR47 ml/min

At the time she was started on lisinopril to treat both the hypertension and act as a renoprotective agent. Lisinopril had been titrated up to treatment dose. Her current bloods are as follows:

K+4.9 mmol/l
Creatinine123 µmol/l
eGFR44 ml/min

Of the following options, what is the most appropriate course of action?
notes:
The correct answer is that no action is required in this scenario. When initiating ACE inhibitors, it is expected and acceptable to see a rise in creatinine of up to 30% from baseline and/or a fall in eGFR. In this case, the creatinine has risen from 116 to 123 µmol/l (a 6% increase) and the eGFR has fallen from 47 to 44 ml/min, both of which are within acceptable limits. The potassium has also remained within the normal range. These changes reflect the normal physiological response to ACE inhibition and do not indicate a need to adjust or stop treatment.

Stopping lisinopril and arranging investigations to exclude renal artery stenosis would be inappropriate as the changes in renal function are minor and expected. Investigation for renal artery stenosis would only be indicated if there was a significant deterioration in renal function (>30% rise in creatinine), resistant hypertension, or other clinical features suggestive of renovascular disease.

Switching to an angiotensin 2 receptor blocker would not be appropriate as the current changes in renal function are acceptable and ARBs would have similar effects on renal function as ACE inhibitors work through a similar mechanism.

Switching to a different ACE inhibitor would not help as all ACE inhibitors have the same effect on renal function and would be expected to produce similar changes in creatinine and eGFR.

Reducing the dose of lisinopril is not necessary as the changes in renal function are within acceptable limits. Reducing the dose would potentially compromise the beneficial renoprotective effects of the medication in this patient with diabetic nephropathy.

title: Chronic kidney disease: hypertension
body:
The majority of patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) will require more than two drugs to treat hypertension. ACE inhibitors are first line and are particularly helpful in proteinuric renal disease (e.g. diabetic nephropathy). As these drugs tend to reduce filtration pressure a small fall in glomerular filtration pressure (GFR) and rise in creatinine can be expected. NICE suggest that a decrease in eGFR of up to 25% or a rise in creatinine of up to 30% is acceptable, although any rise should prompt careful monitoring and exclusion of other causes (e.g. NSAIDs). A rise greater than this may indicate underlying renovascular disease.

Furosemide is useful as a anti-hypertensive in patients with CKD, particularly when the GFR falls to below 45 ml/min*. It has the added benefit of lowering serum potassium. High doses are usually required. If the patient becomes at risk of dehydration (e.g. Gastroenteritis) then consideration should be given to temporarily stopping the drug

*the NKF K/DOQI guidelines suggest a lower cut-off of less than 30 ml/min
links:
KDIGO Clinical Practice Guideline36
Management of Blood Pressure in Chronic Kidney Disease


NICE910
2021 Chronic kidney disease: assessment and management guidelines


NKF K/DOQI83
Use of diuretics in CKD
media:
Understanding Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
Rhesus Medicine - YouTube30

questions:
A 78-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner with several small lesions on her forehead. She explains that they have been present for some years and have not significantly changed in appearance or size. She has no significant past medical history and is a retired farmer.

On examination, the lesions range from several millimetres to 1cm in diameter. They have the appearance of scaly, pink plaques. Two of them appear hyperkeratotic.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
notes:
The description here is that of actinic keratoses (AKs), also known as solar keratoses. These are common premalignant skin lesions that develop due to chronic sun exposure, hinted at here by the patient's former occupation as a farmer. They occur in sun-exposed areas, typically as small, crusty or scaly lesions. They may be pink, red, brown or skin-coloured. Multiple lesions are often present. The absence of significant change or growth is reassuring in this scenario and supports the diagnosis of AK. The most appropriate treatment option listed here is topical fluorouracil. A 2-3 week course is usually given, although often leads to inflammation of the surrounding skin, for which topical hydrocortisone is useful.

Cautery may be used to remove larger lesions, especially hyperkeratotic lesions, in combination with other techniques such as curettage. As a first step, however, topical treatment should be employed.

Curettage may be used for thicker lesions. However, as an initial step, topical fluorouracil should be tried.

Mohs surgery is a technique used to examine margins in real-time while a suspicious lesion is being removed. It is unnecessary for AKs.

Topical betamethasone is a corticosteroid used for a variety of skin conditions. It does not routinely play a role in the management of AKs.
question:
A 78-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner with several small lesions on her forehead. She explains that they have been present for some years and have not significantly changed in appearance or size. She has no significant past medical history and is a retired farmer.

On examination, the lesions range from several millimetres to 1cm in diameter. They have the appearance of scaly, pink plaques. Two of them appear hyperkeratotic.

A 2-3 week course is usually given, although often leads to inflammation of the surrounding skin, for which topical hydrocortisone is useful.

Curettage may be used for thicker lesions. However, as an initial step, topical fluorouracil should be tried.

Topical betamethasone is a corticosteroid used for a variety of skin conditions. It does not routinely play a role in the management of AKs.
title: Actinic keratoses
body:
Actinic, or solar, keratoses (AK) is a common premalignant skin lesion that develops as a consequence of chronic sun exposure

Features
  • small, crusty or scaly, lesions
  • may be pink, red, brown or the same colour as the skin
  • typically on sun-exposed areas e.g. temples of head
  • multiple lesions may be present


Management options include
  • prevention of further risk: e.g. sun avoidance, sun cream
  • fluorouracil cream: typically a 2 to 3 week course. The skin will become red and inflamed - sometimes topical hydrocortisone is given following fluorouracil to help settle the inflammation
  • topical diclofenac: may be used for mild AKs. Moderate efficacy but much fewer side-effects
  • topical imiquimod: trials have shown good efficacy
  • cryotherapy
  • curettage and cautery
concept: Actinic keratoses are premalignant and may be found incidentally on those with high cumulative sun exposure in primary care
links:
British Association of Dermatologists1110
2017 Actinic keratoses guidelines


DermNet NZ2211
Actinic keratoses


Primary Care Dermatology Society157
Actinic keratosis

questions: A 54-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and benign prostatic hyperplasia is referred to dermatology due to a number of lesions over his shin. On examination symmetrical, erythematous, tender, nodules are found. The lesions have started to heal without scarring. What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
The correct answer is Erythema nodosum. This is a panniculitis characterised by tender, erythematous nodules typically appearing on the anterior surface of the lower legs in a bilateral and symmetrical distribution. The key features in this case supporting the diagnosis are the symmetrical distribution, the tender and erythematous nature of the lesions, and their resolution without scarring. While diabetes is mentioned in the history, it is not directly relevant to this presentation.

Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum typically presents as yellow-brown, atrophic plaques with telangiectasia and a waxy appearance. While it is associated with diabetes mellitus, the lesions are usually not tender and tend to heal with scarring, unlike the presentation described in this case.

Pyoderma gangrenosum typically begins as a pustule that rapidly develops into a painful ulcer with a violaceous undermined border. It is usually unilateral and leaves significant scarring. The presentation described lacks these characteristic features.

Syphilis in its secondary stage can present with cutaneous manifestations, but these typically include a copper-coloured, non-tender, maculopapular rash affecting the trunk and extremities, including palms and soles. The presentation described does not fit with any stage of syphilis.

Pretibial myxoedema presents as firm, waxy, non-tender plaques or nodules on the anterior shin and is specifically associated with Graves' disease. The lesions are typically non-tender and non-erythematous, unlike the presentation in this case. Additionally, there is no history of thyroid disease mentioned.
question: A 54-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and benign prostatic hyperplasia is referred to dermatology due to a number of lesions over his shin. On examination symmetrical, erythematous, tender, nodules are found. The lesions have started to heal without scarring. What is the most likely diagnosis?
question_notes:
The correct answer is Erythema nodosum. This is a panniculitis characterised by tender, erythematous nodules typically appearing on the anterior surface of the lower legs in a bilateral and symmetrical distribution. The key features in this case supporting the diagnosis are the symmetrical distribution, the tender and erythematous nature of the lesions, and their resolution without scarring. While diabetes is mentioned in the history, it is not directly relevant to this presentation.

Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum typically presents as yellow-brown, atrophic plaques with telangiectasia and a waxy appearance. While it is associated with diabetes mellitus, the lesions are usually not tender and tend to heal with scarring, unlike the presentation described in this case.

Pyoderma gangrenosum typically begins as a pustule that rapidly develops into a painful ulcer with a violaceous undermined border. It is usually unilateral and leaves significant scarring. The presentation described lacks these characteristic features.

Syphilis in its secondary stage can present with cutaneous manifestations, but these typically include a copper-coloured, non-tender, maculopapular rash affecting the trunk and extremities, including palms and soles. The presentation described does not fit with any stage of syphilis.

Pretibial myxoedema presents as firm, waxy, non-tender plaques or nodules on the anterior shin and is specifically associated with Graves' disease. The lesions are typically non-tender and non-erythematous, unlike the presentation in this case. Additionally, there is no history of thyroid disease mentioned.
title: Shin lesions
body:
The differential diagnosis of shin lesions includes the following conditions:
  • erythema nodosum
  • pretibial myxoedema
  • pyoderma gangrenosum
  • necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum

Below are the characteristic features:

Erythema nodosum
  • symmetrical, erythematous, tender, nodules which heal without scarring
  • most common causes are streptococcal infections, sarcoidosis, inflammatory bowel disease and drugs (penicillins, sulphonamides, oral contraceptive pill)

Pretibial myxoedema
  • symmetrical, erythematous lesions seen in Graves' disease
  • shiny, orange peel skin

Pyoderma gangrenosum
  • initially small red papule
  • later deep, red, necrotic ulcers with a violaceous border
  • idiopathic in 50%, may also be seen in inflammatory bowel disease, connective tissue disorders and myeloproliferative disorders

Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum
  • shiny, painless areas of yellow/red skin typically on the shin of diabetics
  • often associated with telangiectasia
links:
DermIS.net1412
Picture of pretibial myxoedema


DermNet NZ145
Pyoderma gangrenosum


DermNet NZ134
Erythema nodosum


DermNet NZ112
Necrobiosis lipoidica

9221.concept_text: Diabetes, waxy yellow shin lesions - necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum

9223.concept_text: Grave's disease, orange peel shin lesions - pretibial myxoedema

questions: A 52-year-old man with a history of epilepsy is reviewed. Since having his medication change he has experienced a 'numbness' of his hands and feet. On examination he has reduced sensation in a glove-and-stocking distribution associated with a reduced ankle reflex. He is also noted to have lymphadenopathy in the cervical and inguinal region and some bleeding around the gums. Which one of the following medications is he most likely to have been taking?
notes:
The correct answer is Phenytoin. The patient's presentation of peripheral neuropathy, lymphadenopathy, and bleeding gums suggests that he has been taking phenytoin. Phenytoin is an antiepileptic drug that can cause side effects such as peripheral neuropathy, characterized by numbness and reduced sensation in a glove-and-stocking distribution. Additionally, phenytoin can cause gingival hyperplasia, which may lead to bleeding gums. Lymphadenopathy is another potential side effect of phenytoin.

The other options are less likely to be responsible for the patient's symptoms:

Carbamazepine is an antiepileptic drug that can cause side effects such as dizziness, ataxia, and diplopia. While it has been associated with some cases of peripheral neuropathy, it is not commonly linked to lymphadenopathy or bleeding gums.

Topiramate is another antiepileptic medication that can cause side effects like weight loss, cognitive impairment, and kidney stones. It is not typically associated with peripheral neuropathy, lymphadenopathy or bleeding gums.

Sodium valproate is an antiepileptic drug that can cause gastrointestinal disturbances, tremor, and hair loss. It does not typically cause peripheral neuropathy or the other symptoms described in this case.

Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic medication known for causing skin rashes (including Stevens-Johnson syndrome), headache and dizziness. Peripheral neuropathy, lymphadenopathy and bleeding gums are not common side effects of lamotrigine.
question: A 52-year-old man with a history of epilepsy is reviewed. Since having his medication change he has experienced a 'numbness' of his hands and feet. On examination he has reduced sensation in a glove-and-stocking distribution associated with a reduced ankle reflex. He is also noted to have lymphadenopathy in the cervical and inguinal region and some bleeding around the gums. Which one of the following medications is he most likely to have been taking?
question_notes:
The correct answer is Phenytoin. The patient's presentation of peripheral neuropathy, lymphadenopathy, and bleeding gums suggests that he has been taking phenytoin. Phenytoin is an antiepileptic drug that can cause side effects such as peripheral neuropathy, characterized by numbness and reduced sensation in a glove-and-stocking distribution. The other options are less likely to be responsible for the patient's symptoms:

Carbamazepine is an antiepileptic drug that can cause side effects such as dizziness, ataxia, and diplopia. While it has been associated with some cases of peripheral neuropathy, it is not commonly linked to lymphadenopathy or bleeding gums.

Topiramate is another antiepileptic medication that can cause side effects like weight loss, cognitive impairment, and kidney stones. It is not typically associated with peripheral neuropathy, lymphadenopathy or bleeding gums.

Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic medication known for causing skin rashes (including Stevens-Johnson syndrome), headache and dizziness. Peripheral neuropathy, lymphadenopathy and bleeding gums are not common side effects of lamotrigine.
title: Phenytoin
body:
Phenytoin is used in the management of seizures.

Mechanism of action
  • binds to sodium channels increasing their refractory period

Adverse effects

Phenytoin is associated with a large number of adverse effects. These may be divided into acute, chronic, idiosyncratic and teratogenic. Phenytoin is also an inducer of the P450 system.

Acute
  • initially: dizziness, diplopia, nystagmus, slurred speech, ataxia
  • later: confusion, seizures

Chronic
  • common: gingival hyperplasia (secondary to increased expression of platelet derived growth factor, PDGF), hirsutism, coarsening of facial features, drowsiness
  • megaloblastic anaemia (secondary to altered folate metabolism)
  • peripheral neuropathy
  • enhanced vitamin D metabolism causing osteomalacia
  • lymphadenopathy
  • dyskinesia

Idiosyncratic
  • fever
  • rashes, including severe reactions such as toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • hepatitis
  • Dupuytren's contracture*
  • aplastic anaemia
  • drug-induced lupus

Teratogenic
  • associated with cleft palate and congenital heart disease

Monitoring

Phenytoin levels do not need to be monitored routinely but trough levels, immediately before dose should be checked if:
  • adjustment of phenytoin dose
  • suspected toxicity
  • detection of non-adherence to the prescribed medication

*although not listed in the BNF
links:
BNF217
Phenytoin

5034.concept_text: Phenytoin is a P450 enzyme inducer

6333.concept_text: Phenytoin may cause coarsening of facial features

6338.concept_text: Phenytoin may cause toxic epidermal necrolysis

questions:
A 4-year-old girl presents to her GP with her father. He reports that his daughter has been feeling generally unwell with a sore throat and headache. She has a temperature of 38.1ºC. On examination, she has a coarse red blanching rash on the neck and chest. Her tongue is bright red. She is up to date with all vaccinations.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
Scarlet fever is the correct answer. This is a typical presentation of scarlet fever. Specifically, remember the 'coarse red rash' and 'strawberry tongue'. Manage with 10 days of phenoxymethylpenicillin or azithromycin if there is a suspected allergy to penicillin.

Kawasaki disease is different in that the fever typically lasts 5 days or longer. It also presents with an erythematous polymorphous rash, strawberry tongue, cervical lymphadenopathy, bilateral conjunctivitis, oedema, erythema, and skin peeling of the hands and feet.

Parvovirus B19 infection often presents with a diffuse erythematous facial rash appearing on one or both cheeks (resembling a 'slapped cheek') in children. An erythematous maculopapular rash on the trunk, back, and limbs may develop a few days after the facial rash.

Rubella typically causes a non-confluent, maculopapular rash that starts behind the ears, spreads to the face and neck, and then to the trunk and extremities. The rash is transient, lasting between 3-5 days, and there may be associated cervical lymphadenopathy.

Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome is a potentially life-threatening condition, and symptoms may include fever, headache, skin rash, confusion, vomiting, or diarrhoea.
question:
A 4-year-old girl presents to her GP with her father. He reports that his daughter has been feeling generally unwell with a sore throat and headache. She has a temperature of 38.1ºC. On examination, she has a coarse red blanching rash on the neck and chest. Her tongue is bright red. She is up to date with all vaccinations.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
question_notes:
Scarlet fever is the correct answer. This is a typical presentation of scarlet fever. Specifically, remember the 'coarse red rash' and 'strawberry tongue'. Manage with 10 days of phenoxymethylpenicillin or azithromycin if there is a suspected allergy to penicillin.

Kawasaki disease is different in that the fever typically lasts 5 days or longer. It also presents with an erythematous polymorphous rash, strawberry tongue, cervical lymphadenopathy, bilateral conjunctivitis, oedema, erythema, and skin peeling of the hands and feet.

Parvovirus B19 infection often presents with a diffuse erythematous facial rash appearing on one or both cheeks (resembling a 'slapped cheek') in children. An erythematous maculopapular rash on the trunk, back, and limbs may develop a few days after the facial rash.

Rubella typically causes a non-confluent, maculopapular rash that starts behind the ears, spreads to the face and neck, and then to the trunk and extremities. The rash is transient, lasting between 3-5 days, and there may be associated cervical lymphadenopathy.

title: Scarlet fever
body:
Scarlet fever is a reaction to erythrogenic toxins produced by Group A haemolytic streptococci (usually Streptococcus pyogenes). It is more common in children aged 2 - 6 years with the peak incidence being at 4 years.

Scarlet fever is spread via the respiratory route by inhaling or ingesting respiratory droplets or by direct contact with nose and throat discharges, (especially during sneezing and coughing).

Scarlet fever has an incubation period of 2-4 days and typically presents with:
  • fever: typically lasts 24 to 48 hours
  • malaise, headache, nausea/vomiting
  • sore throat
  • 'strawberry' tongue
  • rash
    • fine punctate erythema ('pinhead') which generally appears first on the torso and spares the palms and soles
    • children often have a flushed appearance with circumoral pallor. The rash is often more obvious in the flexures
    • it is often described as having a rough 'sandpaper' texture
    • desquamination occurs later in the course of the illness, particularly around the fingers and toes

© Image used on license from DermNet NZ

Diagnosis
  • a throat swab is normally taken but antibiotic treatment should be commenced immediately, rather than waiting for the results

Management
  • oral penicillin V for 10 days
  • patients who have a penicillin allergy should be given azithromycin
  • children can return to school 24 hours after commencing antibiotics
  • scarlet fever is a notifiable disease

Scarlet fever is usually a mild illness but may be complicated by:
  • otitis media: the most common complication
  • rheumatic fever: typically occurs 20 days after infection
  • acute glomerulonephritis: typically occurs 10 days after infection
  • invasive complications (e.g. bacteraemia, meningitis, necrotizing fasciitis) are rare but may present acutely with life-threatening illness

Image sourced from Wikipedia
concept: Scarlet fever classically presents with a sore throat, fever, headache,  bright red tongue and a coarse, red rash
media:
Scarlet fever
Medicosis Perfectionalis - YouTube213

5058.concept_text: Treat scarlet fever in patients who are well and do not require admission (who have no penicillin allergy) with 10 days of oral penicillin V

11676.concept_text: Scarlet fever classically presents with a sore throat, fever, headache,  bright red tongue and a coarse, red rash
